    <title>Private Network Access: introducing preflights</title>
    <link href="https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/private-network-access-preflight/" />
    <updated>2022-01-06T00:00:00+00:00</updated>
    <id>https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/private-network-access-preflight/</id>
    
      
      
      <author>
        <name><name>Titouan Rigoudy</name></name>
      </author>
      
      
      <author>
        <name><name>Eiji Kitamura</name></name>
      </author>
      
    
    <content type="html"><h2 id="introduction" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#introduction" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Introduction</h2>
<p>Chrome is deprecating direct access to private network endpoints from public
websites as part of the
<a href="https://wicg.github.io/private-network-access/">Private Network Access</a> (PNA)
specification.</p>
<p>Chrome will start sending a CORS preflight request ahead of any <a href="#what-is-private-network-access">private
network request</a> for a subresource, which asks
for explicit permission from the target server. This preflight request will
carry a new header, <code>Access-Control-Request-Private-Network: true</code>, and the
response to it must carry a corresponding header,
<code>Access-Control-Allow-Private-Network: true</code>.</p>
<p>The aim is to protect users from <a href="https://portswigger.net/web-security/csrf">cross-site request forgery (CSRF) attacks</a>
targeting routers and other devices on private networks. These <a href="https://securityaffairs.co/wordpress/22743/cyber-crime/soho-pharming-attack.html">attacks have
affected hundreds of thousands of users</a>,
allowing attackers to redirect them to malicious servers.</p>
<h2 id="rollout-plan" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#rollout-plan" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Rollout plan</h2>
<p>Chrome will roll this change out in two phases to give websites time to notice
the change and adjust accordingly.</p>
<ol>
<li>In Chrome 98:
<ul>
<li>Chrome sends preflight requests ahead of private network subresource
requests.</li>
<li>Preflight failures only display warnings in DevTools, without otherwise
affecting the private network requests.</li>
<li>Chrome gathers compatibility data and reaches out to the largest
affected websites.</li>
<li>We expect this to be broadly compatible with existing websites.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>In Chrome 101 at the earliest:
<ul>
<li>This will begin <em>only</em> if and when compatibility data indicates that the
change is safe enough and we've outreached directly when necessary.</li>
<li>Chrome enforces that preflight requests must succeed, otherwise failing
the requests.</li>
<li><a href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/origin-trials/#deprecation-trials">A deprecation trial</a> starts at
the same time to allow for websites affected by this phase to request a
time extension. The trial will last for at least 6 months.</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ol>
<h2 id="what-is-private-network-access-pna" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#what-is-private-network-access-pna" aria-hidden="true">#</a> What is Private Network Access (PNA)</h2>
<p><a href="https://wicg.github.io/private-network-access/">Private Network Access</a>
(formerly known as <a href="https://web.dev/cors-rfc1918-feedback/">CORS-RFC1918</a>)
restricts the ability of websites to send requests to servers on private
networks.</p>
<p>Chrome has already implemented part of the specification: as of Chrome 96, only
secure contexts are allowed to make private network requests. Refer to our
<a href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/private-network-access-update/">previous blog post</a> for details.</p>
<p>The specification also extends the Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS)
protocol so that websites must now explicitly request a grant from servers
on private networks before being allowed to send arbitrary requests.</p>
<div class="aside aside--key-term"><div class="aside__label gap-bottom-300"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M10.22 9.49l-5.91 6c-.77.8-.7 2.05.08 2.85L.77 22h5.68l.74-.75c.78.81 1.95.86 2.73.05l5.96-6.05-5.66-5.76zm12.46-4l-2.82-2.87c-.78-.8-2.07-.84-2.84-.04l-5.75 5.85 5.66 5.75 5.69-5.78c.77-.81.83-2.11.06-2.91z"></path></svg><span>Key Term</span></div>
<p><strong>Private network requests</strong> are requests whose target server's IP address is
more private than that from which the request initiator was fetched. For example,
a request from a public website (<code>https://example.com</code>) to a private website
(<code>http://router.local</code>), or a request from a private website to localhost.</p>
</div>
<figure>
<img alt="Requests are private when a more available network sends a request to a    less available network." decoding="async" height="420" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 800px) 800px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/5bLcN5HBih35ykCSpj0z.jpg?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/5bLcN5HBih35ykCSpj0z.jpg?auto=format&w=200 200w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/5bLcN5HBih35ykCSpj0z.jpg?auto=format&w=228 228w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/5bLcN5HBih35ykCSpj0z.jpg?auto=format&w=260 260w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/5bLcN5HBih35ykCSpj0z.jpg?auto=format&w=296 296w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/5bLcN5HBih35ykCSpj0z.jpg?auto=format&w=338 338w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/5bLcN5HBih35ykCSpj0z.jpg?auto=format&w=385 385w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/5bLcN5HBih35ykCSpj0z.jpg?auto=format&w=439 439w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/5bLcN5HBih35ykCSpj0z.jpg?auto=format&w=500 500w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/5bLcN5HBih35ykCSpj0z.jpg?auto=format&w=571 571w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/5bLcN5HBih35ykCSpj0z.jpg?auto=format&w=650 650w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/5bLcN5HBih35ykCSpj0z.jpg?auto=format&w=741 741w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/5bLcN5HBih35ykCSpj0z.jpg?auto=format&w=845 845w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/5bLcN5HBih35ykCSpj0z.jpg?auto=format&w=964 964w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/5bLcN5HBih35ykCSpj0z.jpg?auto=format&w=1098 1098w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/5bLcN5HBih35ykCSpj0z.jpg?auto=format&w=1252 1252w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/5bLcN5HBih35ykCSpj0z.jpg?auto=format&w=1428 1428w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/5bLcN5HBih35ykCSpj0z.jpg?auto=format&w=1600 1600w" width="800">
  <figcaption>
    Relationship between public, private, local networks in Private Network
    Access (CORS-RFC1918)
  </figcaption>
</figure>
<p>Learn more at <a href="https://web.dev/cors-rfc1918-feedback/">Feedback wanted: CORS for private networks (RFC1918)</a>.</p>
<h2 id="preflight-requests" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#preflight-requests" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Preflight requests</h2>
<h3 id="background" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#background" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Background</h3>
<p>Preflight requests are a mechanism introduced by the <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/HTTP/CORS">Cross-Origin Resource
Sharing (CORS)</a> standard used
to request permission from a target website before sending it an HTTP request
that might have side effects. This ensures that the target server understands
the CORS protocol and significantly reduces the risk of CSRF attacks.</p>
<p>The permission request is sent as an <code>OPTIONS</code> HTTP request with specific <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/HTTP/CORS#the_http_request_headers">CORS
request headers</a>
describing the upcoming HTTP request. The response must carry specific <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/HTTP/CORS#the_http_response_headers">CORS
response headers</a>
explicitly agreeing to the upcoming request.</p>
<img alt="Sequence diagram which represents CORS preflight. An OPTIONS HTTP    request is sent to the target, which returns a 200 OK. Then the CORS    request header is sent, returning a CORS response header" decoding="async" height="450" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 390px) 390px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/FDj760C71e4YW8eJ0pid.jpg?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/FDj760C71e4YW8eJ0pid.jpg?auto=format&w=200 200w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/FDj760C71e4YW8eJ0pid.jpg?auto=format&w=228 228w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/FDj760C71e4YW8eJ0pid.jpg?auto=format&w=260 260w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/FDj760C71e4YW8eJ0pid.jpg?auto=format&w=296 296w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/FDj760C71e4YW8eJ0pid.jpg?auto=format&w=338 338w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/FDj760C71e4YW8eJ0pid.jpg?auto=format&w=385 385w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/FDj760C71e4YW8eJ0pid.jpg?auto=format&w=439 439w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/FDj760C71e4YW8eJ0pid.jpg?auto=format&w=500 500w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/FDj760C71e4YW8eJ0pid.jpg?auto=format&w=571 571w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/FDj760C71e4YW8eJ0pid.jpg?auto=format&w=650 650w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/FDj760C71e4YW8eJ0pid.jpg?auto=format&w=741 741w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/FDj760C71e4YW8eJ0pid.jpg?auto=format&w=780 780w" width="390">
<h3 id="new-in-pna" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#new-in-pna" aria-hidden="true">#</a> What's new in Private Network Access</h3>
<p>A new pair of request and response headers is introduced to preflight requests:</p>
<ul>
<li><code>Access-Control-Request-Private-Network: true</code> is set on all PNA preflight requests</li>
<li><code>Access-Control-Allow-Private-Network: true</code> must be set on all PNA preflight responses</li>
</ul>
<p>Preflight requests for PNA are sent for all private network requests,
regardless of request method and
<a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/Request/mode">mode</a>. They are sent
ahead of requests in <code>cors</code> mode as well as <code>no-cors</code> and all other modes. This
is because all private network requests can be used for CSRF attacks,
regardless of request mode and whether or not the response contents are made
available to the initiator.</p>
<div class="aside aside--note">
<p>If the private network request is made in <code>cors</code> mode, then CORS headers must
be set on the final response, in addition to the preflight response.</p>
</div>
<p>Preflight requests for PNA are also sent for same-origin requests, if the
target IP address is more private than the initiator. This is unlike regular
CORS, where preflight requests are only for cross-origin requests. Preflight
requests for same-origin requests guard against
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DNS_rebinding">DNS rebinding</a> attacks.</p>
<h3 id="examples" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#examples" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Examples</h3>
<p>Observable behavior depends on the
<a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/Request/mode">request's mode</a>.</p>
<h4 id="no-cors-mode" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#no-cors-mode" aria-hidden="true">#</a> No-CORS mode</h4>
<p>Say <code>https://foo.example/index.html</code> embeds
<code>&lt;img src=&quot;https://bar.example/cat.gif&quot; alt=&quot;dancing cat&quot;/&gt;</code>, and
<code>bar.example</code> resolves to <code>192.168.1.1</code>, a private IP address according to
<a href="https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc1918">RFC 1918</a>.</p>
<p>Chrome first sends a preflight request:</p>
<pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">HTTP/1.1 OPTIONS /cat.gif<br>Origin: https://foo.example<br>Access-Control-Request-Private-Network: true</code></pre>
<p>For this request to succeed, the server must respond with:</p>
<pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">HTTP/1.1 204 No Content<br>Access-Control-Allow-Origin: https://foo.example<br>Access-Control-Allow-Private-Network: true</code></pre>
<div class="aside aside--warning"><div class="aside__label gap-bottom-300"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M23 21L12 2 1 21h22zm-12-3v-2h2v2h-2zm0-4h2v-4h-2v4z"></path></svg><span>Warning</span></div>
<p>The server can set <code>Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *</code>, though this is dangerous
and discouraged. Private network resources should rarely be accessible to all
origins, so think carefully about the risks involved in setting such a header.</p>
</div>
<p>Then Chrome will send the actual request:</p>
<pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">HTTP/1.1 GET /cat.gif<br>...</code></pre>
<p>To which the server can respond normally.</p>
<h4 id="cors-mode" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#cors-mode" aria-hidden="true">#</a> CORS mode</h4>
<p>Say <code>https://foo.example/index.html</code> runs the following code:</p>
<pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">await fetch('https://bar.example/delete-everything', {<br>  method: 'PUT',<br>  credentials: 'include',<br>})</code></pre>
<p>Again, say <code>bar.example</code>  resolves to <code>192.168.1.1</code>.</p>
<p>Chrome first sends a preflight request:</p>
<pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">HTTP/1.1 OPTIONS /delete-everything<br>Origin: https://foo.example<br>Access-Control-Request-Method: PUT<br>Access-Control-Request-Credentials: true<br>Access-Control-Request-Private-Network: true</code></pre>
<p>For this request to succeed, the server must respond with:</p>
<pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">HTTP/1.1 204 No Content<br>Access-Control-Allow-Origin: https://foo.example<br>Access-Control-Allow-Methods: PUT<br>Access-Control-Allow-Credentials: true<br>Access-Control-Allow-Private-Network: true</code></pre>
<p>Then Chrome will send the actual request:</p>
<pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">HTTP/1.1 PUT /delete-everything<br>Origin: https://foo.example</code></pre>
<p>To which the server can respond per usual CORS rules:</p>
<pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">HTTP/1.1 200 OK<br>Access-Control-Allow-Origin: https://foo.example</code></pre>
<h2 id="how-to-know-if-your-website-is-affected" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#how-to-know-if-your-website-is-affected" aria-hidden="true">#</a> How to know if your website is affected</h2>
<p>Starting in Chrome 98, if a private network request is detected, a preflight
request will be sent ahead of it. If this preflight request fails, the final
request will still be sent, but a warning will be surfaced in the DevTools
issues panel.</p>
<img alt="A failed preflight request warning in the Devtools Issues panel. This states:    ensure private network requests are only made to resources that allow them,    along with details about the specific request and listed affected resources." class="screenshot" decoding="async" height="556" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 800px) 800px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/AgZzPf3NkMWQ0Cm6Puu0.png?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/AgZzPf3NkMWQ0Cm6Puu0.png?auto=format&w=200 200w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/AgZzPf3NkMWQ0Cm6Puu0.png?auto=format&w=228 228w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/AgZzPf3NkMWQ0Cm6Puu0.png?auto=format&w=260 260w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/AgZzPf3NkMWQ0Cm6Puu0.png?auto=format&w=296 296w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/AgZzPf3NkMWQ0Cm6Puu0.png?auto=format&w=338 338w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/AgZzPf3NkMWQ0Cm6Puu0.png?auto=format&w=385 385w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/AgZzPf3NkMWQ0Cm6Puu0.png?auto=format&w=439 439w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/AgZzPf3NkMWQ0Cm6Puu0.png?auto=format&w=500 500w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/AgZzPf3NkMWQ0Cm6Puu0.png?auto=format&w=571 571w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/AgZzPf3NkMWQ0Cm6Puu0.png?auto=format&w=650 650w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/AgZzPf3NkMWQ0Cm6Puu0.png?auto=format&w=741 741w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/AgZzPf3NkMWQ0Cm6Puu0.png?auto=format&w=845 845w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/AgZzPf3NkMWQ0Cm6Puu0.png?auto=format&w=964 964w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/AgZzPf3NkMWQ0Cm6Puu0.png?auto=format&w=1098 1098w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/AgZzPf3NkMWQ0Cm6Puu0.png?auto=format&w=1252 1252w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/AgZzPf3NkMWQ0Cm6Puu0.png?auto=format&w=1428 1428w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/AgZzPf3NkMWQ0Cm6Puu0.png?auto=format&w=1600 1600w" width="800">
<p>Affected preflight requests can also be viewed and diagnosed in the network panel:</p>
<img alt="A failed preflight request in the DevTools Network panel for localhost    gives a 501 status." class="screenshot" decoding="async" height="265" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 800px) 800px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/aysOX5wKA1kme8HyV3t0.png?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/aysOX5wKA1kme8HyV3t0.png?auto=format&w=200 200w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/aysOX5wKA1kme8HyV3t0.png?auto=format&w=228 228w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/aysOX5wKA1kme8HyV3t0.png?auto=format&w=260 260w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/aysOX5wKA1kme8HyV3t0.png?auto=format&w=296 296w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/aysOX5wKA1kme8HyV3t0.png?auto=format&w=338 338w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/aysOX5wKA1kme8HyV3t0.png?auto=format&w=385 385w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/aysOX5wKA1kme8HyV3t0.png?auto=format&w=439 439w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/aysOX5wKA1kme8HyV3t0.png?auto=format&w=500 500w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/aysOX5wKA1kme8HyV3t0.png?auto=format&w=571 571w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/aysOX5wKA1kme8HyV3t0.png?auto=format&w=650 650w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/aysOX5wKA1kme8HyV3t0.png?auto=format&w=741 741w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/aysOX5wKA1kme8HyV3t0.png?auto=format&w=845 845w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/aysOX5wKA1kme8HyV3t0.png?auto=format&w=964 964w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/aysOX5wKA1kme8HyV3t0.png?auto=format&w=1098 1098w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/aysOX5wKA1kme8HyV3t0.png?auto=format&w=1252 1252w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/aysOX5wKA1kme8HyV3t0.png?auto=format&w=1428 1428w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/VbsHyyQopiec0718rMq2kTE1hke2/aysOX5wKA1kme8HyV3t0.png?auto=format&w=1600 1600w" width="800">
<p>To review what happens if preflight success was enforced, you can
<a href="https://www.chromium.org/developers/how-tos/run-chromium-with-flags">pass the following command-line argument</a>,
starting in Chrome 98:</p>
<pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">--enable-features=PrivateNetworkAccessRespectPreflightResults</code></pre>
<p>Any failed preflight request will result in a failed fetch. This can allow you
to test whether your website would work after the
<a href="#rollout-plan">second phase of our rollout plan</a>. Errors can be diagnosed in
the same way as warnings using the DevTools panels mentioned above.</p>
<h2 id="what-to-do-if-your-website-is-affected" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#what-to-do-if-your-website-is-affected" aria-hidden="true">#</a> What to do if your website is affected</h2>
<p>When this change rolls out in Chrome 98, it is not expected to break any
website. However, we strongly encourage you to update affected request paths to
ensure your website keeps running as expected.</p>
<p>There are two solutions available to you:</p>
<ol>
<li>Handle preflight requests on the server side</li>
<li>Disable PNA checks with enterprise policies</li>
</ol>
<h3 id="server-side-requests" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#server-side-requests" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Handle preflight requests server-side</h3>
<p>Update the target server of any affected fetches to handle PNA preflight
requests. First, implement support for standard CORS preflight requests on
affected routes. Then add support for the <a href="#new-in-pna">two new response headers</a>.</p>
<p>When your server receives a preflight request (an <code>OPTIONS</code> request with CORS
headers), the server should check for the presence of an
<code>Access-Control-Request-Private-Network: true</code> header. If this header is
present on the request, the server should examine the <code>Origin</code> header and the
request path along with any other relevant information (such as
<code>Access-Control-Request-Headers</code>) to ensure the request is safe to allow.
Typically, you should allow access to a single origin under your control.</p>
<div class="aside aside--warning"><div class="aside__label gap-bottom-300"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path fill-rule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd" d="M23 21L12 2 1 21h22zm-12-3v-2h2v2h-2zm0-4h2v-4h-2v4z"></path></svg><span>Warning</span></div>
<p>Beware of insecure (non-https) origins, as they are unauthenticated. An on-path
attacker could masquerade as any such origin!</p>
</div>
<p>Once your server has decided to allow the request, it should respond
<code>204 No Content</code> (or <code>200 OK</code>) with the necessary CORS headers and the new PNA
header. These headers include <code>Access-Control-Allow-Origin</code> and
<code>Access-Control-Allow-Private-Network: true</code>, as well as others as needed.</p>
<p>Refer to the <a href="#examples">examples</a> for concrete scenarios.</p>
<h3 id="disable-with-enterprise-policy" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#disable-with-enterprise-policy" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Disable Private Network Access checks using enterprise policies</h3>
<p>If you have administrative control over your users, you can disable Private
Network Access checks using either of the following policies:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://chromeenterprise.google/policies/#InsecurePrivateNetworkRequestsAllowed"><code>InsecurePrivateNetworkRequestsAllowed</code></a></li>
<li><a href="https://chromeenterprise.google/policies/#InsecurePrivateNetworkRequestsAllowedForUrls"><code>InsecurePrivateNetworkRequestsAllowedForUrls</code></a></li>
</ul>
<p>For more information, refer to <a href="https://support.google.com/chrome/a/answer/9037717">Understand Chrome policy
management</a>.</p>
<h2 id="whats-next" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#whats-next" aria-hidden="true">#</a> What's next</h2>
<p>Next up, Chrome will extend Private Network Access checks to cover
<a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/Web_Workers_API">web workers</a>:
dedicated workers, shared workers and service workers. We're tentatively aiming
for Chrome 100 to begin showing warnings.</p>
<p>Then, Chrome will extend Private Network Access checks to cover navigations,
including iframes and popups. We're tentatively aiming for Chrome 102 to start
showing warnings.</p>
<p>In both cases, we will be proceeding cautiously with a similar phased rollout,
in order to give web developers time to adjust and estimate compatibility risk.</p>
<h2 id="acknowledgements" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#acknowledgements" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Acknowledgements</h2>
<p>Cover photo by <a href="https://unsplash.com/@markolsen">Mark Olsen</a> on
<a href="https://unsplash.com/photos/K5j1KgecVC8">Unsplash</a>.</p>
</content>

    <title>COLRv1 Color Gradient Vector Fonts in Chrome 98</title>
    <link href="https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/colrv1-fonts/" />
    <updated>2022-01-06T00:00:00+00:00</updated>
    <id>https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/colrv1-fonts/</id>
    
      
      
      <author>
        <name><name>Dominik Röttsches</name></name>
      </author>
      
      
      <author>
        <name><name>Rod Sheeter</name></name>
      </author>
      
    
    <content type="html"><p><em>Compact, compression-friendly, color vector fonts with all your favorite
gradient flavors.</em></p>
<p>In Chrome 98, the Chrome and Fonts teams have added support for COLRv1, an
evolution of the COLRv0 font format intended to make color fonts widespread by
adding gradients, compositing and blending, and improved internal shape reuse
for crisp and compact font files that compress well.</p>
<div class="aside aside--note">
<p>Examples in this blog post require a browser that supports
COLRv1 fonts. Try viewing this post in Chrome 98 or above.</p>
</div>
<h2 id="color-now" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#color-now" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Color now</h2>
<p>On the web, text is generally drawn in a color specified in CSS. The font does
not define any particular color, it just indicates where pixels should be
placed. That's usually a good thing. CSS lets the author flexibly choose a
color. However, sometimes a glyph contains multiple colors that together have
meaning. For example, this flag <img alt="Transgender flag consisting of pale blue and pale pink stripes." decoding="async" height="16" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 16px) 16px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/8hQhmhh6F8Ff7kquy4mB.png?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/8hQhmhh6F8Ff7kquy4mB.png?auto=format&w=16 16w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/8hQhmhh6F8Ff7kquy4mB.png?auto=format&w=18 18w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/8hQhmhh6F8Ff7kquy4mB.png?auto=format&w=21 21w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/8hQhmhh6F8Ff7kquy4mB.png?auto=format&w=24 24w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/8hQhmhh6F8Ff7kquy4mB.png?auto=format&w=27 27w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/8hQhmhh6F8Ff7kquy4mB.png?auto=format&w=31 31w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/8hQhmhh6F8Ff7kquy4mB.png?auto=format&w=32 32w" width="16"> with light blue, pink, and white stripes would not
convey the same meaning if it was simply drawn in the current text color.</p>
<p>Today, for most users, emojis are the only color fonts they see. Emojis
typically appear on the web via the system emoji font, or by inserting images
(which has its own complications, <img alt="Panda emoji with sad facial expression." decoding="async" height="16" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 16px) 16px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/uFlyeIll20cgXsyl7npT.png?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/uFlyeIll20cgXsyl7npT.png?auto=format&w=16 16w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/uFlyeIll20cgXsyl7npT.png?auto=format&w=18 18w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/uFlyeIll20cgXsyl7npT.png?auto=format&w=21 21w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/uFlyeIll20cgXsyl7npT.png?auto=format&w=24 24w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/uFlyeIll20cgXsyl7npT.png?auto=format&w=27 27w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/uFlyeIll20cgXsyl7npT.png?auto=format&w=31 31w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/uFlyeIll20cgXsyl7npT.png?auto=format&w=32 32w" width="16">). Large file
sizes especially for bitmap-based color fonts have made it difficult to use web
fonts for emoji. By supporting COLRv1, we hope to see a proliferation of
creative color font use on the web and beyond.</p>
<h2 id="show-me-your-colors" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#show-me-your-colors" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Show me your colors</h2>
<p>We've created a couple of examples for you to play with:</p>
<div style="height: 420px; width: 100%;"> <iframe style="height: 100%; width: 100%; border: 0;" title="colrv1-bungee-spice on Glitch" src="https://glitch.com/embed/#!/embed/colrv1-bungee-spice?attributionHidden=true&sidebarCollapsed=true&path=index.html&previewSize=100" allow="camera; clipboard-read; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; geolocation; microphone; midi" loading="lazy"></iframe>
</div>
<div style="height: 420px; width: 100%;"> <iframe style="height: 100%; width: 100%; border: 0;" title="colrv1-emoji-vs-cbdt on Glitch" src="https://glitch.com/embed/#!/embed/colrv1-emoji-vs-cbdt?attributionHidden=true&sidebarCollapsed=true&path=index.html&previewSize=100" allow="camera; clipboard-read; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; geolocation; microphone; midi" loading="lazy"></iframe>
</div>
<div style="height: 420px; width: 100%;"> <iframe style="height: 100%; width: 100%; border: 0;" title="colrv1-emoji-grid on Glitch" src="https://glitch.com/embed/#!/embed/colrv1-emoji-grid?attributionHidden=true&sidebarCollapsed=true&path=index.html&previewSize=100" allow="camera; clipboard-read; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; geolocation; microphone; midi" loading="lazy"></iframe>
</div>
<p>The example assets from Google Fonts used in the example are live in the
<a href="https://developers.google.com/fonts/docs/css2">Google Fonts web API</a>. They are
not listed in the directory at <a href="https://fonts.google.com/">fonts.google.com</a> as
they will only work on Chrome 98 or later and showcase experimental work.</p>
<p>You can now make your own COLRv1 fonts using free and open-source tools. Check
out the <a href="https://github.com/googlefonts/nanoemoji">nanoemoji font compiler</a>
which allows you to build COLRv1 fonts from SVG source images, then try them in
Chrome 98 or later. Try making your own spin on Bungee Spice by changing the
gradient colors using
<a href="https://github.com/rsheeter/Bungee/blob/main/README.md#build-your-own-copy">these instructions</a>.</p>
<p>For example, you might modify the Bungee Spice font to have a blue and red gradient, like this:</p>
<img alt="The word dune in the Bungee Spice color font, toned in blue and red gradients." decoding="async" height="169" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 564px) 564px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/xJDHSfqK292j7JmUa94K.png?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/xJDHSfqK292j7JmUa94K.png?auto=format&w=200 200w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/xJDHSfqK292j7JmUa94K.png?auto=format&w=228 228w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/xJDHSfqK292j7JmUa94K.png?auto=format&w=260 260w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/xJDHSfqK292j7JmUa94K.png?auto=format&w=296 296w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/xJDHSfqK292j7JmUa94K.png?auto=format&w=338 338w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/xJDHSfqK292j7JmUa94K.png?auto=format&w=385 385w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/xJDHSfqK292j7JmUa94K.png?auto=format&w=439 439w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/xJDHSfqK292j7JmUa94K.png?auto=format&w=500 500w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/xJDHSfqK292j7JmUa94K.png?auto=format&w=571 571w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/xJDHSfqK292j7JmUa94K.png?auto=format&w=650 650w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/xJDHSfqK292j7JmUa94K.png?auto=format&w=741 741w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/xJDHSfqK292j7JmUa94K.png?auto=format&w=845 845w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/xJDHSfqK292j7JmUa94K.png?auto=format&w=964 964w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/xJDHSfqK292j7JmUa94K.png?auto=format&w=1098 1098w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/xJDHSfqK292j7JmUa94K.png?auto=format&w=1128 1128w" width="564">
<p>Tweet your results to <a href="https://twitter.com/googlefonts">@googlefonts</a> 🙂 Why not try a radial or sweep gradient?</p>
<h2 id="new-with-colrv1" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#new-with-colrv1" aria-hidden="true">#</a> New with COLRv1</h2>
<p>The font format supports multiple ways to support color, all with different
tradeoffs – but none have been successful on the web so far. (To learn more
about the tradeoffs,
<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BmqYm5Wwz8M">take a look at Dominik's BlinkOn 15 conference talk</a>.)
Chrome 98 brings support for COLRv1, an evolution of COLRv0. We hope that
COLRv1's combination of graphic capabilities and compact files will make it a
good choice for many color font use cases. COLRv1 adds gradients,
<a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/compositing-1/">compositing, and blending</a>, and improves
internal shape reuse to make even more compact files.</p>
<p>COLRv1 has expressive capability roughly equivalent to
<a href="https://svgwg.org/specs/svg-native/">SVG Native</a> plus
<a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/compositing-1/">blending and compositing</a> added on
top. There are four types of color fills: solid colors, linear gradients, radial
gradients, and sweep/conic gradients. COLRv1 lets you reposition and transform
glyph elements using a full set of translate, rotate, sheer, and scale
transformations. Plus, it features support for font variations and reuses
existing shape definition formats in the font.</p>
<figure> <img alt="Blue     and purple crystal ball emoji with reused stars on a brown base." decoding="async" height="360" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 360px) 360px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/GRJkXpRBl8vdCAWcIjA1.png?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/GRJkXpRBl8vdCAWcIjA1.png?auto=format&w=200 200w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/GRJkXpRBl8vdCAWcIjA1.png?auto=format&w=228 228w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/GRJkXpRBl8vdCAWcIjA1.png?auto=format&w=260 260w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/GRJkXpRBl8vdCAWcIjA1.png?auto=format&w=296 296w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/GRJkXpRBl8vdCAWcIjA1.png?auto=format&w=338 338w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/GRJkXpRBl8vdCAWcIjA1.png?auto=format&w=385 385w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/GRJkXpRBl8vdCAWcIjA1.png?auto=format&w=439 439w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/GRJkXpRBl8vdCAWcIjA1.png?auto=format&w=500 500w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/GRJkXpRBl8vdCAWcIjA1.png?auto=format&w=571 571w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/GRJkXpRBl8vdCAWcIjA1.png?auto=format&w=650 650w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/GRJkXpRBl8vdCAWcIjA1.png?auto=format&w=720 720w" width="360"> <figcaption>Shape reuse in the crystal ball
    emoji</figcaption> </figure>
<p>Think about the crystal ball emoji as an example: The star-shaped highlights are
the same shape but different sizes, which means just one shape can be
repositioned and reused without duplication inside the file. The format allows
you to reuse a full glyph within a new glyph, without having to redundantly
encode the same shapes for each glyph. Imagine a decorative color font with
floral decorations, where the same flower shapes are placed on different letters
by just referencing existing color glyphs. For the web font use case, COLRv1
compresses well under woff2. For example, a test build of Twemoji using COLRv1
takes about 1.2 MB inflated, but is about 0.6MB in woff2 form. A build of the
full Noto Emoji Glyph set is reduced from 9MB for the bitmap version to 1.85MB
in COLRv1+woff2 form.</p>
<figure>
<img alt="Bar chart comparing Noto Emoji as Bitmap font and COLRv1 font, about 9MB vs. 1.85MB" decoding="async" height="495" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 800px) 800px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/OULzoVLf1nYWZCaZWhBa.png?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/OULzoVLf1nYWZCaZWhBa.png?auto=format&w=200 200w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/OULzoVLf1nYWZCaZWhBa.png?auto=format&w=228 228w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/OULzoVLf1nYWZCaZWhBa.png?auto=format&w=260 260w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/OULzoVLf1nYWZCaZWhBa.png?auto=format&w=296 296w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/OULzoVLf1nYWZCaZWhBa.png?auto=format&w=338 338w, <h2 id="color-font-use-cases" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#color-font-use-cases" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Color font use cases</h2>
<h3 id="catchy-headlines" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#catchy-headlines" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Catchy headlines</h3>
<p>A fresh color font makes visual highlights, headlines, and banners really pop
out.</p>
<figure> <div style="height: 420px; width: 100%;"> <iframe style="height: 100%; width: 100%; border: 0;" title="colrv1-underware-plakato on Glitch" src="https://glitch.com/embed/#!/embed/colrv1-underware-plakato?attributionHidden=true&sidebarCollapsed=true&path=index.html&previewSize=100" allow="camera; clipboard-read; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; geolocation; microphone; midi" loading="lazy"></iframe>

<h3 id="no-more-image-replacement-emoji-fonts" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#no-more-image-replacement-emoji-fonts" aria-hidden="true">#</a> No more image replacement: emoji fonts</h3>
<p>If you support user generated content, your users probably use emojis. Today
it's very common to scan text and replace any emoji encountered with images to
ensure consistent cross-platform rendering and the ability to support newer
emojis than the OS supports. Those images then have to be switched back to text
during clipboard operations. Here's a real example:</p>
<figure>
<img alt="A code snippet showing inline images as img tags and metadata as part of a chat history" decoding="async" height="88" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 800px) 800px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/dgpLYdWxn0G94lH0rVWI.png?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/dgpLYdWxn0G94lH0rVWI.png?auto=format&w=200 200w, </figure>
<p>If you have an emoji font you just render the text in the font, like this:</p>
<pre class="language-html"><code class="language-html"><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation">&lt;</span>style</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span><span class="token style"><span class="token language-css"><br><span class="token atrule"><span class="token rule">@import</span> <span class="token url"><span class="token function">url</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Noto+Color+Emoji<span class="token punctuation">)</span></span><span class="token punctuation">;</span></span><br><br><span class="token selector">.emoji</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><br>  <span class="token property">font-family</span><span class="token punctuation">:</span> <span class="token string">"Noto Color Emoji"</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> sans-serif<span class="token punctuation">;</span><br><span class="token punctuation">}</span><br></span></span><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation">&lt;/</span>style</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span><br><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation">&lt;</span>span</span> <span class="token attr-name">class</span><span class="token attr-value"><span class="token punctuation attr-equals">=</span><span class="token punctuation">"</span>emoji<span class="token punctuation">"</span></span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span>🙂<span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation">&lt;/</span>span</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span></code></pre>
<p>Similarly, in an emoji reaction component, COLRv1 offers the opportunity to use
a compact font file instead of a catalog of image assets.</p>

Reaction Picker on GitHub</figcaption> </figure>
<p>Imagine how many images you'd have to fetch for a complete emoji picker!</p>
<h3 id="color-in-icon-fonts" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#color-in-icon-fonts" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Color in icon fonts</h3>
<p>Using color in icon fonts adds clarity and makes glyphs easier to understand.</p>
<figure> <img alt="Three green icons in black outline" decoding="async" height="354" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 400px) 400px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/MHHhcD15T0j4q0J3jhPW.png?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/MHHhcD15T0j4q0J3jhPW.png?auto=format&w=200 200w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/MHHhcD15T0j4q0J3jhPW.png?auto=format&w=228 228w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/MHHhcD15T0j4q0J3jhPW.png?auto=format&w=260 260w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/MHHhcD15T0j4q0J3jhPW.png?auto=format&w=296 296w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/MHHhcD15T0j4q0J3jhPW.png?auto=format&w=338 338w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/MHHhcD15T0j4q0J3jhPW.png?auto=format&w=385 385w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/MHHhcD15T0j4q0J3jhPW.png?auto=format&w=439 439w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/MHHhcD15T0j4q0J3jhPW.png?auto=format&w=500 500w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/MHHhcD15T0j4q0J3jhPW.png?auto=format&w=571 571w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/MHHhcD15T0j4q0J3jhPW.png?auto=format&w=650 650w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/MHHhcD15T0j4q0J3jhPW.png?auto=format&w=741 741w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/MHHhcD15T0j4q0J3jhPW.png?auto=format&w=800 800w" width="400"> <figcaption>
Material two-tone icons from <a href="https://fonts.google.com/icons">https://fonts.google.com/icons</a>
</figcaption> </figure>
<h3 id="artistic-expression" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#artistic-expression" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Artistic expression</h3>
<p>Space-efficient color fonts enable new forms of artistic expression in text on
the web. This example of a Kufi-style Arabic font uses color gradients as an
artistic interpretation of what the ink flow of traditional calligraphy could
look like when applied to the Kufi style of Arabic writing, which originates
from not being written with nib and ink but carved in stone.</p>
<figure><img alt="Arabic letters with gradients from black to red." decoding="async" height="220" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 600px) 600px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/6jBXnyaHip2elGTHNl0x.png?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/6jBXnyaHip2elGTHNl0x.png?auto=format&w=200 200w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/6jBXnyaHip2elGTHNl0x.png?auto=format&w=228 228w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/6jBXnyaHip2elGTHNl0x.png?auto=format&w=260 260w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/6jBXnyaHip2elGTHNl0x.png?auto=format&w=296 296w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/6jBXnyaHip2elGTHNl0x.png?auto=format&w=338 338w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/6jBXnyaHip2elGTHNl0x.png?auto=format&w=385 385w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/6jBXnyaHip2elGTHNl0x.png?auto=format&w=439 439w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/6jBXnyaHip2elGTHNl0x.png?auto=format&w=500 500w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/6jBXnyaHip2elGTHNl0x.png?auto=format&w=571 571w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/6jBXnyaHip2elGTHNl0x.png?auto=format&w=650 650w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/6jBXnyaHip2elGTHNl0x.png?auto=format&w=741 741w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/6jBXnyaHip2elGTHNl0x.png?auto=format&w=845 845w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/6jBXnyaHip2elGTHNl0x.png?auto=format&w=964 964w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/6jBXnyaHip2elGTHNl0x.png?auto=format&w=1098 1098w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/roKb5a4ddjOSoIbxRFI9kDeuVvE2/6jBXnyaHip2elGTHNl0x.png?auto=format&w=1200 1200w" width="600">
<figcaption><a href="https://github.com/aliftype/reem-kufi">Reem Kufi Ink</a>,
an Arabic font by Khaled Hosny</figcaption> </figure>
<h2 id="feature-detection" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#feature-detection" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Feature detection</h2>
<p>At the moment, figuring out whether a browser engine supports a specific color
font format is possible by means of user-agent sniffing or by searching in a
library like <a href="https://github.com/RoelN/ChromaCheck">ChromaCheck</a> by
<a href="https://twitter.com/pixelambacht">@PixelAmbacht</a> to test rendering of color
glyphs on Canvas. Both solutions are not optimal. Feature testing should detect
only a specific feature itself and avoid user agent sniffing. The ChromaCheck
library should not need to perform resource-intensive 2D canvas operations for
determining support.</p>
<p>The Chrome team wants to improve that and has started a series of discussions
[<a href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/6520">1</a>,
<a href="https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/6791">2</a>] in the CSS working group
to provide information on browser font technology support in JavaScript and
declaratively in CSS. The team plans to release efficient feature detection for
color font and other font technologies in a future version of Chrome.</p>
<p>If you would like to use color fonts in your project right now when COLRv1
support is limited to Chrome, there are two ways you can do that: Ask your font
vendor for a COLRv1 font that contains monochrome glyphs too. User agents that
don’t support COLRv1 will fall back to rendering monochrome
glyphs. Alternatively, you can use the ChromaCheck library or user agent
sniffing to determine whether COLRv1 support is available. Then you deliver CSS
that loads COLRv1 fonts in supporting user agents and use an alternative font
format such as COLRv0, a bitmap font format or OpenType SVG in other browsers.</p>
<h2 id="css-font-palette-support" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#css-font-palette-support" aria-hidden="true">#</a> CSS font-palette support</h2>
<p>It would be tremendously useful if using a different set of colors would not
require a new font. Thankfully, a mechanism exists: the
<a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-fonts-4/#font-palette-prop">font-palette CSS property</a>. The
Chrome team is working on adding
<a href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1170794">support for font-palette in Chrome</a>.</p>
<h2 id="colrv1-fonts-you" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#colrv1-fonts-you" aria-hidden="true">#</a> COLRv1 fonts &amp; you</h2>
<p>If COLRv1 fonts piques your interest, ask your font vendor about a COLRv1 color
font to use in your project, try the <a href="#show-me-your-colors">examples and demos</a>
above, or why not dive right in and experiment with
<a href="https://github.com/rsheeter/Bungee/blob/main/README.md#build-your-own-copy">making your own</a>?</p>
<p>If you have feedback on COLRv1 in Chrome, post to the
<a href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev">blink-dev mailing list</a>,
or file an issue in our <a href="http://crbug.com/">issue tracker</a>. If you have feedback
on the COLRv1 font format itself, file an issue at the
<a href="https://github.com/googlefonts/colr-gradients-spec/issues">COLRv1 specification GitHub repository</a>.</p>
<p>With Chrome 98, we’re excited about how COLRv1 brings a whole new level of
typographic creativity to the web.</p>
<h2 id="learn-more" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#learn-more" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Learn more</h2>
<p>If you're interested in more details, we have a couple more resources for you:</p>
<p>To learn how COLRv1 works and how it's implemented in Chrome, check out Dominik's BlinkOn 15 conference talk.</p>
<div class="youtube">
  <iframe class="youtube__embed" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/BmqYm5Wwz8M" title="youtube embed" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen="" loading="lazy"></iframe>
</div>
<ul>
<li>International Unicode Conference #45: Vector Color Fonts, talk by Roderick
Sheeter, Peter Constable, and Dominik Röttsches
(<a href="https://vimeo.com/645566639">video</a>,
<a href="https://www.unicodeconference.org/program.htm#:~:text=Vector%20Color%20Fonts">talk details</a>)</li>
<li><a href="https://github.com/googlefonts/nanoemoji">nanoemoji font compiler</a>, producing
COLRv1 fonts from SVG images</li>
<li>Google Fonts’
<a href="https://github.com/googlefonts/color-fonts">color-fonts GitHub repository</a>
containing current builds of Noto Emoji, Twemoji, and other sample fonts</li>
<li>DJR's showcase of the <a href="https://tools.djr.com/misc/bradley-initials/">Bradley Initials</a> font, exploring COLRv1</li>
<li><a href="https://pixelambacht.nl/chromacheck/">ChromaCheck tool and library</a> to
feature-detect available color font technologies</li>
</ul>
<h2 id="acknowledgements" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#acknowledgements" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Acknowledgements</h2>
<p>Many thanks to Behdad Esfahbod, Cosimo Lupo, Peter Constable, Ben Wagner, Werner
Lemberg, Dave Crossland, Vladimir Levantovsky, Jonathan Kew, Laurence Penney,
Chris Lilley, David Jonathan Ross, Underware, Just van Rossum, Roel Nieskens, and
others for their contributions to COLRv1.</p>
</content>

      </author>
      
    
    <content type="html"><div class="youtube">
  <iframe class="youtube__embed" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/eXaog4gUIXI" title="youtube embed" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen="" loading="lazy"></iframe>
</div>
<p>Here's what you need to know:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="#webtransport"><code>WebTransport</code></a> is a new option for sending real time messages
between the client and server.</li>
<li>You can use <a href="#script-type-feature-detection">feature detection</a> to see what
types of scripts a browser supports.</li>
<li><a href="#new-array-prototypes">Searching arrays from the end</a> becomes a little
easier.</li>
<li>And there's plenty <a href="#more">more</a>.</li>
</ul>
<p>Happy New Year! I'm <a href="https://petelepage.com/">Pete LePage</a>. Let's dive in and
see what's new for developers in Chrome 97.</p>
<h2 id="webtransport" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#webtransport" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Web Transport</h2>
<p>If you're using Web Sockets or the WebRTC Data Channel API to send messages
between your server and the page, there's a new option for you. <code>WebTransport</code>
is a new API offering low-latency, bidirectional, client-server messaging.</p>
<p>It has lower latency than WebSockets, and unlike the RTC Data Channel API,
which is designed for peer-to-peer messaging, the Web Transport API is
specifically designed for client-server messaging.</p>
<p>It supports sending data, reliably with its streams APIs, and unreliably with
its datagram APIs. It's supported in web workers. And because it exposes a
Streams compliant interface, it supports optimizations around backpressure.</p>
<p>To use it, you'll need a server that supports HTTP/3, which is generally
easier than setting up and maintaining a WebRTC server. Open a new
<code>WebTransport</code> instance, wait for it to connect, and you can start sending
data.</p>
<pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> url <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token string">'https://example.com:4999/foo/bar'</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br><span class="token keyword">const</span> transport <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">WebTransport</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>url<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br><span class="token keyword">await</span> transport<span class="token punctuation">.</span>ready<span class="token punctuation">;</span><br><br><span class="token keyword">const</span> writer <span class="token operator">=</span> transport<span class="token punctuation">.</span>datagrams<span class="token punctuation">.</span>writable<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">getWriter</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br><span class="token keyword">const</span> data1 <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token keyword">new</span> <span class="token class-name">Uint8Array</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token number">65</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">66</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">67</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br>writer<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">write</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>data1<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span></code></pre>
<p>Check out the article <a href="https://web.dev/webtransport/">Experimenting with WebTransport</a> on
web.dev for complete details.</p>
<h2 id="script-type-feature-detection" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#script-type-feature-detection" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Script type feature detection</h2>
<p>Today, we can use the <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/script#attr-nomodule"><code>nomodule</code> attribute</a> to detect support
for JavaScript modules in the browser. But there are several new feature
proposals in the pipeline, like import maps, speculation rules, and bundle
preloading. We need a way to know what a browser supports.</p>
<p>Enter <a href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5712146835963904"><code>HTMLScriptElement.supports()</code></a>. You can use it to
determine what types of scripts you can use, and send the browser the best
option.</p>
<pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">if</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span>HTMLScriptElement<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">supports</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'importmap'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><br>  <span class="token comment">// Use &lt;script type="importmap" ...></span><br><span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token keyword">else</span> <span class="token keyword">if</span> <span class="token punctuation">(</span>HTMLScriptElement<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">supports</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token string">'module'</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><br>  <span class="token comment">// Use &lt;script type="module" ...></span><br><span class="token punctuation">}</span> <span class="token keyword">else</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><br>  <span class="token comment">// Use classic method...</span><br><span class="token punctuation">}</span></code></pre>
<h2 id="new-array-prototypes" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#new-array-prototypes" aria-hidden="true">#</a> New array prototypes</h2>
<p>I love it when JavaScript gets easier. <code>Array</code> and <code>TypedArray</code> now support
the <code>findLast()</code> and <code>findLastIndex()</code> static methods.</p>
<p>These functions are effectively the same as <a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/find"><code>find()</code></a> and
<a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/findIndex"><code>findIndex()</code></a>, but search from the end of an array
instead of the beginning.</p>
<p>For example, to find the last number in an array that is larger than ten,
call <code>findLast()</code> with a test function that checks if the value is greater
than ten, and you're good to go.</p>
<pre class="language-js"><code class="language-js"><span class="token keyword">const</span> array1 <span class="token operator">=</span> <span class="token punctuation">[</span><span class="token number">5</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">12</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">8</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">130</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">44</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">3</span><span class="token punctuation">,</span> <span class="token number">6</span><span class="token punctuation">]</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br><br><span class="token keyword">function</span> <span class="token function">greaterThanTen</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span><span class="token parameter">val</span><span class="token punctuation">)</span> <span class="token punctuation">{</span><br>  <span class="token keyword">return</span> val <span class="token operator">></span> <span class="token number">10</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br><span class="token punctuation">}</span><br><br><span class="token keyword">const</span> last <span class="token operator">=</span> array1<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">findLast</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>greaterThanTen<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br><span class="token comment">// 44</span><br><br><span class="token keyword">const</span> lIdx <span class="token operator">=</span> array1<span class="token punctuation">.</span><span class="token function">findLastIndex</span><span class="token punctuation">(</span>greaterThanTen<span class="token punctuation">)</span><span class="token punctuation">;</span><br><span class="token comment">// 4</span></code></pre>
<h2 id="chrome-100" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#chrome-100" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Emulate Chrome 100 in the UA string</h2>
<p>In just a few months, we'll hit Chrome 100, a <strong>three</strong> digit version number.
Any code that checks version numbers, or parses the UA string, should be
checked to make sure it handles three digits.</p>
<p>There's a flag called <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/force-major-version-to-100/"><code>#force-major-version-to-100</code></a> that
will change the current version number to 100, so you can make sure
everything works as expected.</p>
<img alt="Chrome flags page highlighting new #force-major-version-to-100 option" decoding="async" height="533" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 800px) 800px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/0g2WvpbGRGdVs0aAPc6ObG7gkud2/4drS8JxKXgtzSAxyM6WF.png?auto=format" <h2 id="more" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#more" aria-hidden="true">#</a> And more!</h2>
<p>Of course there's plenty more.</p>
<p>New lines in form entries are now <a href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5654547184746496">normalized</a> in the same
way as Gecko and WebKit, improving interoperability between browsers.</p>
<p>We're standardizing client hint names by prefixing them with <code>sec-ch</code>.
For example, <code>dpr</code> becomes <code>sec-ch-dpr</code>. We'll continue to support existing
versions of these hints, but you should plan for their eventual deprecation
and removal.</p>
<p>Closed <a href="https://chromestatus.com/feature/5032469667512320"><code>&lt;details&gt;</code> elements are now searchable</a> and can be
linked to. These hidden elements will automatically expand when find in page,
<code>ScrollToTextFragment</code>, and element fragment navigation are used.</p>
<h2 id="further-reading" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#further-reading" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Further reading</h2>
<p>This covers only some of the key highlights. Check the links below for
additional changes in Chrome 97.</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/new-in-devtools-97/">What's new in Chrome DevTools (97)</a></li>

<li><a href="https://v8.dev/blog/v8-release-97">What's new in JavaScript in Chrome 97</a></li>
<li><a href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+log/96.0.4664.50..97.0.4692.71">Chromium source repository change list</a></li>
<li><a href="https://chromiumdash.appspot.com/schedule">Chrome release calendar</a></li>
</ul>
<h2 id="subscribe" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#subscribe" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Subscribe</h2>
<p>To stay up to date, <a href="https://goo.gl/6FP1a5">subscribe</a>
to <a href="https://www.youtube.com/user/ChromeDevelopers/">Chrome Developers YouTube channel</a>,
and you'll get an email notification whenever we launch a new video.</p>
<p>I'm Pete LePage, and as soon as Chrome 98 is released, I'll be right here to
tell you what's new in Chrome!</p>

    <title>Full accessibility tree in Chrome DevTools</title>
    <link href="https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/full-accessibility-tree/" />
    <updated>2021-12-13T00:00:00+00:00</updated>
    <id>https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/full-accessibility-tree/</id>
    
      
      
      <author>
        <name><name>Johan Bay</name></name>
      </author>
      
    
    <content type="html"><div class="aside aside--note">
<p>Interested in helping improve DevTools? Sign up to participate in <a href="https://google.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_9YbKj35IGoGsDBj?reserved=1&amp;utm_source=Website%20feature&amp;Q_Language=en&amp;utm_medium=own_web&amp;utm_campaign=Q4&amp;productTag=chrm&amp;campaignDate=November2020&amp;referral_code=UXFm430458">Google User Research here</a>.</p>
</div>
<p>Chrome DevTools is launching a full accessibility tree making it easier for developers to get an overview of the whole tree. In this post find out how this tree is created and how to use it in your work.</p>
<p><video autoplay="" class="screenshot" loop="" muted="">      <source src="https://storage.googleapis.com/web-dev-uploads/video/gGNVLl64MBQvhaYBXAAuRiOs3r92/XQNBCFrPG8YqNSOloDE8.mp4" type="video/mp4">    </video></p>
<h2 id="what-is-the-accessibility-tree" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#what-is-the-accessibility-tree" aria-hidden="true">#</a> What is the accessibility tree?</h2>
<p>Assistive technology such as screen readers use Chromium’s accessibility API to interact with web content. The underlying model of this API is the accessibility tree: <strong>a tree of accessibility objects that assistive technology can query for attributes and properties and perform actions on</strong>. Web developers shape and manipulate the accessibility tree primarily through DOM properties such as <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/html-aria/">ARIA attributes for HTML</a>.</p>
<p>In <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/devtools/">Chrome DevTools</a>, we provide the accessibility pane to help developers understand how their content is exposed to assistive technology. Concretely, when a node is selected in the DOM tree viewer, the properties of the corresponding accessibility node displays in the pane together with a view of the node's ancestors and its immediate children.</p>
<img alt="The Chrome DevTools accessibility pane." decoding="async" height="547" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 535px) 535px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/gGNVLl64MBQvhaYBXAAuRiOs3r92/NiCDcnAxDts5kG4ZgOeg.png?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/gGNVLl64MBQvhaYBXAAuRiOs3r92/NiCDcnAxDts5kG4ZgOeg.png?auto=format&w=200 200w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/gGNVLl64MBQvhaYBXAAuRiOs3r92/NiCDcnAxDts5kG4ZgOeg.png?auto=format&w=228 228w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/gGNVLl64MBQvhaYBXAAuRiOs3r92/NiCDcnAxDts5kG4ZgOeg.png?auto=format&w=260 260w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/gGNVLl64MBQvhaYBXAAuRiOs3r92/NiCDcnAxDts5kG4ZgOeg.png?auto=format&w=296 296w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/gGNVLl64MBQvhaYBXAAuRiOs3r92/NiCDcnAxDts5kG4ZgOeg.png?auto=format&w=338 338w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/gGNVLl64MBQvhaYBXAAuRiOs3r92/NiCDcnAxDts5kG4ZgOeg.png?auto=format&w=385 385w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/gGNVLl64MBQvhaYBXAAuRiOs3r92/NiCDcnAxDts5kG4ZgOeg.png?auto=format&w=439 439w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/gGNVLl64MBQvhaYBXAAuRiOs3r92/NiCDcnAxDts5kG4ZgOeg.png?auto=format&w=500 500w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/gGNVLl64MBQvhaYBXAAuRiOs3r92/NiCDcnAxDts5kG4ZgOeg.png?auto=format&w=571 571w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/gGNVLl64MBQvhaYBXAAuRiOs3r92/NiCDcnAxDts5kG4ZgOeg.png?auto=format&w=650 650w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/gGNVLl64MBQvhaYBXAAuRiOs3r92/NiCDcnAxDts5kG4ZgOeg.png?auto=format&w=741 741w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/gGNVLl64MBQvhaYBXAAuRiOs3r92/NiCDcnAxDts5kG4ZgOeg.png?auto=format&w=845 845w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/gGNVLl64MBQvhaYBXAAuRiOs3r92/NiCDcnAxDts5kG4ZgOeg.png?auto=format&w=964 964w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/gGNVLl64MBQvhaYBXAAuRiOs3r92/NiCDcnAxDts5kG4ZgOeg.png?auto=format&w=1070 1070w" width="535">
<h2 id="how-is-the-tree-created" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#how-is-the-tree-created" aria-hidden="true">#</a> How is the tree created?</h2>
<p>Before we get to what this new full tree view looks like in DevTools, let us briefly go over what the accessibility tree is in more tangible terms. The accessibility tree is a derivative of the DOM tree. Its structure is roughly the same, but simplified to remove nodes with no semantic content such as a <code>&lt;div&gt;</code> element purely used for styling. Each node in the tree has a role such as <code>Button</code> or <code>Heading</code>, and often a name that can be either from ARIA attributes or derived from the node’s contents. If we look at an HTML document:</p>
<pre class="language-html"><code class="language-html"><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation">&lt;</span>html</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span><br><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation">&lt;</span>head</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span><br>  <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation">&lt;</span>title</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span>How old are you?<span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation">&lt;/</span>title</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span><br><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation">&lt;/</span>head</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span><br><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation">&lt;</span>body</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span><br>  <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation">&lt;</span>label</span> <span class="token attr-name">for</span><span class="token attr-value"><span class="token punctuation attr-equals">=</span><span class="token punctuation">"</span>age<span class="token punctuation">"</span></span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span>Age<span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation">&lt;/</span>label</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span><br>  <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation">&lt;</span>input</span> <span class="token attr-name">id</span><span class="token attr-value"><span class="token punctuation attr-equals">=</span><span class="token punctuation">"</span>age<span class="token punctuation">"</span></span> <span class="token attr-name">type</span><span class="token attr-value"><span class="token punctuation attr-equals">=</span><span class="token punctuation">"</span>number<span class="token punctuation">"</span></span> <span class="token attr-name">name</span><span class="token attr-value"><span class="token punctuation attr-equals">=</span><span class="token punctuation">"</span>age<span class="token punctuation">"</span></span> <span class="token attr-name">value</span><span class="token attr-value"><span class="token punctuation attr-equals">=</span><span class="token punctuation">"</span>42<span class="token punctuation">"</span></span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span><br>  <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation">&lt;</span>div</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span><br>    <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation">&lt;</span>button</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span>Back<span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation">&lt;/</span>button</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span><br>    <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation">&lt;</span>button</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span>Next<span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation">&lt;/</span>button</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span><br>  <span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation">&lt;/</span>div</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span><br><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation">&lt;/</span>body</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span><br><span class="token tag"><span class="token tag"><span class="token punctuation">&lt;/</span>html</span><span class="token punctuation">></span></span></code></pre>
<p>The renderer in Chromium, named Blink, derives an internal accessibility tree roughly as follows.</p>
<pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">role='rootWebArea' focusable name='How old are you?'<br>  role='genericContainer' ignored<br>    role='genericContainer' ignored<br>      role='labelText'<br>        role='staticText' name='Age'<br>      role='spinButton' editable focusable name='Age' value='42'<br>        role='genericContainer' editable<br>          role='staticText' editable name='42'<br>      role='genericContainer'<br>        role='button' focusable name='Back'<br>          role='staticText' name='Back'<br>        role='button' focusable name='Next'<br>          role='staticText' name='Next'</code></pre>
<p>Note that this representation contains multiple superfluous nodes with role <code>genericContainer</code>, which seemingly contradicts the statement above that the accessibility tree is a simplified derivative of the DOM tree. Still, most of these nodes only occur in the internal tree and would not be exposed to assistive technology. Since DevTools collects its accessibility information directly from the renderer process, this is the tree representation that DevTools handles.</p>
<div class="aside aside--note">
<p>The HTML example was borrowed from <a href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:docs/accessibility/browser/how_a11y_works.md">here</a> which also contains more information about how accessibility works in Chromium.</p>
</div>

<h3 id="lazy-tree-construction" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#lazy-tree-construction" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Lazy tree construction</h3>

<h3 id="live" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#live" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Live</h3>
<p>The new tree view is live and dynamically updates if the accessibility tree changes in the renderer. It hooks into the same mechanics that would notify assistive technology of changes to the tree, and uses that to emit events to the DevTools frontend with updated nodes.
In practice, the CDP backend listens for updates to the tree, keeps track of which nodes have been requested before, and sends events to the DevTools frontend if any of these nodes changes.</p>

<h2 id="the-tale-of-many-trees" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#the-tale-of-many-trees" aria-hidden="true">#</a> The tale of many trees</h2>
<p>In the description of <a href="#what-is-the-accessibility-tree">what the accessibility tree is</a> you learned how Blink constructs an accessibility tree for the DOM it is rendering, and DevTools fetches this tree through CDP. While this is true, we left out some complications in this description. In reality, there are quite a lot of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blind_men_and_an_elephant">different ways to experience</a> the accessibility tree in Chromium.
When designing the new tree view for DevTools, we have made some choices along the way about what part of Chromium’s accessibility internals we wanted to surface.</p>
<h3 id="platforms" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#platforms" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Platforms</h3>
<p>Every platform has a different accessibility API and while the shape of the tree is the same across all platforms, the API for interacting with the tree is different, and the names of attributes can differ. DevTools shows Chromium’s internal tree where roles and attributes tend to match those defined in the <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria-1.1/">ARIA</a> specification.</p>
<h3 id="multiple-frames-and-site-isolation" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#multiple-frames-and-site-isolation" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Multiple frames and site isolation</h3>
<p>Since Chromium not only puts the content of every tab in different renderer processes but also <a href="https://www.chromium.org/developers/design-documents/site-isolation">isolates cross-site documents in different renderer processes</a>, we have to connect to each out-of-process child document separately over CDP and fetch its accessibility tree. We then stitch these subtrees together on the frontend to give the illusion of one coherent tree, although they live in different renderer processes in Chromium.</p>
<h3 id="ignored-and-uninteresting-nodes" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#ignored-and-uninteresting-nodes" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Ignored and uninteresting nodes</h3>
<p>We hide some nodes per default: ignored nodes, and nodes with role “generic” with no name. These nodes carry no semantic meaning and, in the case of ignored nodes, are not exposed to assistive technology. We hide these nodes to avoid cluttering the tree view. If we did not, the accessibility tree for most web pages would instead look something like this:</p>

<p>On the frontend, we construct the full tree including ignored nodes and only prune them just before rendering the nodes. We do this for two reasons:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>It makes it much simpler to handle node updates from the backend</strong>, since we have the same tree structure on both endpoints. For example, if the node B is removed in the example, we would receive an update for node X (since its children have changed), but if we had pruned that node we would struggle to figure out what to update.</li>
<li><strong>It ensures that all DOM nodes have a corresponding accessibility node.</strong> When the tree is toggled, we select the node corresponding to the node currently selected in the DOM tree. So for the previous example, if the user toggles the tree while the DOM node corresponding to X is selected, we inject X between the nodes A and B and select X in the tree. This allows the user to inspect the accessibility node for all DOM nodes and help determine why the node is ignored.</li>
</ul>
<h2 id="future-ideas" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#future-ideas" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Future ideas</h2>
<p>Launching the new accessibility tree is just the start. We have a few ideas for future projects we could build on top of the new view, but we are also eager to <a href="https://goo.gle/devtools-a11y-tree-feedback">hear your feedback</a>!</p>
<h3 id="alternative-filterings" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#alternative-filterings" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Alternative filterings</h3>
<p>As explained above, we currently filter out nodes that are deemed uninteresting. We could provide a way to disable this behavior and show all nodes, or provide alternative filterings such as <strong>Show landmark nodes</strong> or <strong>Show headings</strong>.</p>
<h3 id="highlight-a11y-issues" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#highlight-a11y-issues" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Highlight a11y issues</h3>
<p>We could incorporate an “accessibility best practice” analysis with the tree and highlight accessibility issues directly on the offending nodes.</p>
<h3 id="surface-accessibility-actions-in-devtools" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#surface-accessibility-actions-in-devtools" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Surface accessibility actions in DevTools</h3>
<p>The tree we currently show is purely one-way: It allows us to get an idea of what information would be fed to assistive technology when browsing a specific webpage. Accessibility actions represent the communication in the other direction: They allow assistive technology to act on the presented UI. We could surface such actions in DevTools to allow actions such as “clicking”, scrolling, or changing values on the page using the API available to assistive technology.</p>
</content>
