    <title>Progress in the Privacy Sandbox (November 2021)</title>
    <link href="https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/progress-in-the-privacy-sandbox-2021-11/" />
    <updated>2021-11-30T00:00:00+00:00</updated>
    <id>https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/progress-in-the-privacy-sandbox-2021-11/</id>
    
      
      
      <author>
        <name><name>Rowan Merewood</name></name>
      </author>
      
    
    <content type="html"><p>Welcome to the November edition of &quot;<strong><a href="https://developer.chrome.com/tags/progress-in-the-privacy-sandbox/">Progress in the Privacy
Sandbox</a></strong>,&quot; tracking the milestones on
the path to phasing out third-party cookies in Chrome and working towards a more
private web. Each month we'll share an overview of the updates to the <strong><a href="https://privacysandbox.com/timeline/">Privacy
Sandbox timeline</a></strong> along with news from
across the project. We've also provided an <a href="https://blog.google/around-the-globe/google-europe/update-our-privacy-sandbox-commitments/">update on our Privacy Sandbox
commitments</a>
as we ensure proposals are designed, developed and implemented with regulatory
oversight and input from the UK’s Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) and
Information Commissioner's Office (ICO).</p>
<div class="aside aside--note">
<p>As we approach the end of the year there are fewer changes across the different
proposals, so the update here is also lighter. However, this does mean it's a
good time for testing and addressing questions, which we are always happy to
hear about either on the <a href="https://twitter.com/ChromiumDev">@ChromiumDev Twitter</a>
or the <a href="https://github.com/GoogleChromeLabs/privacy-sandbox-dev-support">developer support
repo</a>.</p>
</div>
<h2 id="events" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#events" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Events</h2>
<p>At the beginning of November we hosted the Chrome Developer Summit, which
included both a Privacy Sandbox segment in the keynote and a few related
questions in the Ask Me Anything (AMA) session. We've <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/cds21-update/">added a summary for
you</a> to read or watch that covers
activities and examples of what to expect as proposals progress through the
discussion, testing, and scaled adoption phases.</p>
<div class="youtube">
  <iframe class="youtube__embed" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/_Ah_ODU3CvA" title="youtube embed" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen="" loading="lazy"></iframe>
</div>
<h2 id="strengthen-cross-site-privacy-boundaries" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#strengthen-cross-site-privacy-boundaries" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Strengthen cross-site privacy boundaries</h2>
<p>Third-party cookies are a key mechanism that enables cross-site tracking.
Phasing them out is a major milestone, but we also need to tackle other forms of
cross-site storage or communication.</p>
<h3 id="federated-credentials-management-api" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#federated-credentials-management-api" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Federated Credentials Management API</h3>
<p><strong><a href="https://github.com/WICG/FedCM">Federated Credentials Management (FedCM)</a></strong> is
the new, more meaningful name for the WebID proposal.  We've reflected this
change in the <a href="https://privacysandbox.com/timeline/">Privacy Sandbox Timeline</a>.
Federated identity is a critical service for the web, but given that it's
explicitly used to share aspects of identity across other sites, there are
implementation details which overlap with cross-site tracking.</p>
<p>The Federated Credentials Management proposal explores a range of options: from
simple migration paths for existing solutions to more private methods of
connecting to services with the bare minimum of information shared.</p>
<p>November also included the bi-annual
<strong><a href="https://www.chromium.org/events/blinkon-15">BlinkOn</a></strong> conference. Blink is
the rendering engine used by Chromium, and BlinkOn is where contributors gather
for engineering presentations and discussions on current projects. The November
BlinkOn included an <strong>overview and Q&amp;A session on FedCM</strong>: you can <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9la0cBhVXac">watch the
recording on YouTube</a>.</p>
<h2 id="preventing-covert-tracking" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#preventing-covert-tracking" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Preventing covert tracking</h2>
<p>As we reduce the options for explicit cross-site tracking, we also need to
address the areas of the web platform that expose identifying information which
enables fingerprinting or covert tracking of users.</p>
<h3 id="user-agent-string-reduction-and-user-agent-client-hints" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#user-agent-string-reduction-and-user-agent-client-hints" aria-hidden="true">#</a> User-Agent string reduction and User-Agent Client Hints</h3>
<p>Progress continues on reducing the information available by default in Chrome's
User-Agent string and providing an improved, active method for requesting that
data via User-Agent Client Hints. We've added a new <strong><a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/user-agent/">User-Agent
Reduction</a> overview</strong> to collate all the
current guidance and updates.</p>
<p>We published new testing resources to help prepare for the changes. The
<strong><a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/user-agent/snippets/">User-Agent reduction code
snippets</a></strong> provide a selection of
examples for transforming the current Chrome User-Agent string to the reduced
format. There is also the new <code>chrome://flags/#force-major-version-to-100</code> entry
which will let you check if the switch to a 3 digit major version causes your
site to malfunction or break.</p>
<p>We have published the <strong><a href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/yZh8Lwr34Ro">Intent to Ship for
Sec-CH-UA-Full-Version-List</a></strong>.
This addresses <a href="https://github.com/WICG/ua-client-hints/issues/196">ecosystem
feedback</a> that the existing
Sec-CH-UA-Full-Version was too tightly bound to the primary browser brand as it
only provided a single value. For example, the current implementation shows:</p>
<p>⬇️ <em>Server response header</em></p>
<pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">Accept-CH: Sec-CH-UA-Full-Version</code></pre>
<p>⬆️ <em>Browser request header</em></p>
<pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">Sec-CH-UA: "Chromium";v="94", "Google Chrome";v="94", ";Not A Brand";v="99"<br>Sec-CH-UA-Full-Version: "94.0.4606.124"</code></pre>
<p>The updated version would provide:</p>
<p>⬇️ <em>Server response header</em></p>
<pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">Accept-CH: Sec-CH-UA-Full-Version-List</code></pre>
<p>⬆️ <em>Browser request header</em></p>
<pre class="language-text"><code class="language-text">Sec-CH-UA: "Chromium";v="94", "Google Chrome";v="94", "Other browser";v="99"<br>Sec-CH-UA-Full-Version-List: "Chromium";v="94.0.4606.124", "Google Chrome";v="94.0.4606.124", "Other browser";v="99.88.77.66"</code></pre>
<div class="aside aside--note">
<p>If you are using <code>Sec-CH-UA-Full-Version</code> then you should plan to migrate to
<code>Sec-CH-UA-Full-Version-List</code> as it will allow us to deprecate
<code>Sec-CH-UA-Full-Version</code> in the future.</p>
</div>
<h3 id="ip-blindness" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#ip-blindness" aria-hidden="true">#</a> IP blindness</h3>
<p>IP addresses by their nature often provide a unique identifier for a client
enabling the necessary communication between browser and server. However, this
also means that a stable IP address over time passively provides a significant
amount of information that can be used for cross-site tracking.</p>
<p>The <strong><a href="https://github.com/bslassey/ip-blindness">IP blindness proposal</a></strong> (also
known as Global Network Address Translation Combined with Audited and Trusted
CDN or HTTP-Proxy Eliminating Reidentification or <strong>Gnatcatcher</strong>) details a two
pronged approach to addressing this issue. The first is <a href="https://github.com/bslassey/ip-blindness/blob/master/near_path_nat.md">Near-Path
NAT</a>
which effectively forwards the browser's connection through an IP privatizing
service which hides the browser's IP address from the site being visited. The
second option builds on the layered nature of the Internet where the
infrastructure that relies on IP address can be wholly separate from the
application running on top of it. The <a href="https://github.com/bslassey/ip-blindness/blob/master/willful_ip_blindness.md">Willful IP
Blindness</a>
proposal explores methods of defining auditable policies for creating and
maintaining that separation.</p>
<p>Both of these ideas are early in the discussion phase with active progress in
the repo, such as the recently posted <a href="https://github.com/bslassey/ip-blindness/blob/master/proposed_willful_ip_blindness_principles.md">Willful IP Blindness
Principles</a>.
You can expect to see discussion continue there and if you're interested in the
network-level details, you can follow the <a href="https://datatracker.ietf.org/wg/masque/about/">Multiplexed Application Substrate
over QUIC Encryption (MASQUE)</a>
Working Group in the IETF.</p>
<h2 id="measure-digital-ads" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#measure-digital-ads" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Measure digital ads</h2>
<p>As the companion to displaying ads without cross-site tracking, we need
privacy-preserving mechanisms to allow measurement of ad effectiveness.</p>
<h3 id="attribution-reporting-api" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#attribution-reporting-api" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Attribution Reporting API</h3>
<p>The <strong><a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/attribution-reporting/">Attribution Reporting
API</a></strong> creates functionality to
measure events on one site, like clicking or viewing an ad, that lead to a
conversion on another site—without enabling cross-site tracking.</p>
<p>We continue to test the API and <strong><a href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/DdjaFmsb4fA">the origin trial has been
extended</a></strong>
through to Chrome 97. Current origin trial tokens expired on October 12th, so
existing testers need to apply for updated tokens to continue testing.</p>
<p>There are two new blog posts up with the latest details on event-level reporting
in the API. <strong><a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/attribution-reporting-event-introduction/">Event-level reports in the Attribution Reporting
API</a></strong>
introduces the concepts and process while <strong><a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/attribution-reporting-event-guide/">Using event-level reports in the
Attribution Reporting
API</a></strong> goes into the
implementation detail with accompanying demo and demo code.</p>
<h2 id="feedback" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#feedback" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Feedback</h2>
<p>As we continue to publish these monthly updates, and progress through the
Privacy Sandbox as a whole, we want to make sure that developers receive the
information and support that they need. Let us know on <a href="https://twitter.com/ChromiumDev">@ChromiumDev
Twitter</a> if there's anything that we could
improve in this series. We'll use your input to continue improving the format.</p>
<p>Check out the <strong><a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/privacy-sandbox/faq/">Privacy Sandbox FAQ</a></strong>, which we
continue to expand based on the issues you submit to the <a href="https://github.com/GoogleChromeLabs/privacy-sandbox-dev-support">developer support
repo</a>. If you
have any questions around testing or implementation on any of the proposals,
come talk to us there.</p>
</content>
  </entry>

    <content type="html"><div class="aside aside--note">
<p>Interested in helping improve DevTools? Sign up to participate in <a href="https://google.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_9YbKj35IGoGsDBj?reserved=1&amp;utm_source=Website%20feature&amp;Q_Language=en&amp;utm_medium=own_web&amp;utm_campaign=Q4&amp;productTag=chrm&amp;campaignDate=November2020&amp;referral_code=UXFm430458">Google User Research here</a>.</p>

  <iframe class="youtube__embed" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/cGotLGL1-Ko" title="youtube embed" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen="" loading="lazy"></iframe>
</div>
<h2 id="recorder" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#recorder" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Preview feature: New Recorder panel</h2>
<p>Use the new <strong>Recorder</strong> panel to record, replay and measure user flows.</p>
<p><a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/devtools/recorder/#open">Open the <strong>Recorder</strong> panel</a>. Follow the instructions on screen to start a new recording.</p>
<p>For example, you can record the coffee checkout process with this <a href="https://coffee-cart.netlify.app/">coffee ordering demo</a> application. After adding a coffee and filling out payment details, you can end the recording, replay the process or click on the <strong>Measure performance</strong> button to measure the user flow in the <strong>Performance</strong> panel.</p>
<p>Go to the <strong>Recorder</strong> panel <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/docs/devtools/recorder/">documentation</a> to learn more with the step-by-step tutorial!</p>
<p>The <strong>Recorder</strong> panel is a preview feature. Our team is still actively working on it and we are looking for your <a href="https://goo.gle/recorder-feedback">feedback</a> for further enhancements.</p>

    <title>Helping developers build powerful, installable web apps</title>
    <link href="https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/pwa-install-features/" />
    <updated>2021-11-23T00:00:00+00:00</updated>
    <id>https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/pwa-install-features/</id>
    
      
      
      <author>
        <name><name>Mustafa Kurtuldu</name></name>
      </author>
      
    
    <content type="html"><h2 id="introduction" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#introduction" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Introduction</h2>
<p>At the beginning of 2020, the Chrome team across mobile and desktop
laid out a plan to improve the discoverability and engagement of
installed web apps. Our work led to a greater than 100% increase in
PWA installation and engagement. We achieved this by researching
existing features, running A/B test experiments and user interviews
to gain insight into users perceptions and expectations. This article
covers how we got there.</p>
<h2 id="unified" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#unified" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Unified install language</h2>
<p>The call-to-action that triggers a PWA install was inconsistent across
the web platform. For Chrome on Android, we had settled on <strong>Add to
home screen</strong>, but on our Desktop Platforms, we
emphasized <strong>Install</strong>. The rationale for this discrepancy came from
a study the team ran in 2016 that compared different strings. The
team found that <strong>Add to home screen</strong> worked better, if only
marginally, on mobile.</p>
<p>A further study on taxonomy in 2019 found no difference, and so the
team wanting to unify the PWA install experience, decided to update
the label to <strong>Install</strong> on Android. A further study in 2021 compared
the language, <strong>Install</strong>, <strong>Get</strong>, and <strong>Download</strong>, and we found
that users understood <strong>Install</strong> as the process that was happening.
Users felt tapping a button with the label <strong>Get</strong> would send the user
to a website, and with <strong>Download</strong> they assumed a file would end up
in their downloads folder or equivalent.</p>
<p>With all this in mind, we concluded that the label <strong>Install</strong> best
fits PWAs. We recommend developers across the web platform adopt
Install as the preferred string going forward.</p>
<h2 id="installicon" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#installicon" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Install icon on desktop</h2>
<p>On our desktop platforms, we have a design pattern that whenever a website
loads a PWA, Chrome will show a pill that appears on the right-hand side of the
omnibox that contains an icon and the label <strong>Install</strong>. After
that, when a user visits a site, only the icon will be present.
Clicking on this pill triggers the installation of a desktop
PWA.</p>
<figure>
<img alt="Original install plus icon." decoding="async" height="228" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 660px) 660px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/RCE9R8Shyh2bMPBZLSJO.png?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/RCE9R8Shyh2bMPBZLSJO.png?auto=format&w=200 200w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/RCE9R8Shyh2bMPBZLSJO.png?auto=format&w=228 228w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/RCE9R8Shyh2bMPBZLSJO.png?auto=format&w=260 260w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/RCE9R8Shyh2bMPBZLSJO.png?auto=format&w=296 296w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/RCE9R8Shyh2bMPBZLSJO.png?auto=format&w=338 338w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/RCE9R8Shyh2bMPBZLSJO.png?auto=format&w=385 385w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/RCE9R8Shyh2bMPBZLSJO.png?auto=format&w=439 439w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/RCE9R8Shyh2bMPBZLSJO.png?auto=format&w=500 500w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/RCE9R8Shyh2bMPBZLSJO.png?auto=format&w=571 571w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/RCE9R8Shyh2bMPBZLSJO.png?auto=format&w=650 650w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/RCE9R8Shyh2bMPBZLSJO.png?auto=format&w=741 741w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/RCE9R8Shyh2bMPBZLSJO.png?auto=format&w=845 845w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/RCE9R8Shyh2bMPBZLSJO.png?auto=format&w=964 964w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/RCE9R8Shyh2bMPBZLSJO.png?auto=format&w=1098 1098w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/RCE9R8Shyh2bMPBZLSJO.png?auto=format&w=1252 1252w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/RCE9R8Shyh2bMPBZLSJO.png?auto=format&w=1320 1320w" width="660">
<figcaption>
Original install plus icon.
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>The icon was initially a plus symbol, partly due to the <strong>Add to home
screen</strong> metaphor used on mobile. However, as mentioned, the language
we used was <strong>Install</strong>. The feedback we received from the developer
community was that this icon was confusing. Furthermore, if a user
used the zoom function to enlarge text, the icon for zoom looked very
similar, confusing the user even more.</p>
<figure>
<img alt="Omnibox bug with zoom and install icons present." decoding="async" height="205" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 660px) 660px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/zliw3izVFXwgQcpxBS8n.png?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/zliw3izVFXwgQcpxBS8n.png?auto=format&w=200 200w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/zliw3izVFXwgQcpxBS8n.png?auto=format&w=228 228w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/zliw3izVFXwgQcpxBS8n.png?auto=format&w=260 260w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/zliw3izVFXwgQcpxBS8n.png?auto=format&w=296 296w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/zliw3izVFXwgQcpxBS8n.png?auto=format&w=338 338w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/zliw3izVFXwgQcpxBS8n.png?auto=format&w=385 385w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/zliw3izVFXwgQcpxBS8n.png?auto=format&w=439 439w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/zliw3izVFXwgQcpxBS8n.png?auto=format&w=500 500w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/zliw3izVFXwgQcpxBS8n.png?auto=format&w=571 571w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/zliw3izVFXwgQcpxBS8n.png?auto=format&w=650 650w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/zliw3izVFXwgQcpxBS8n.png?auto=format&w=741 741w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/zliw3izVFXwgQcpxBS8n.png?auto=format&w=845 845w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/zliw3izVFXwgQcpxBS8n.png?auto=format&w=964 964w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/zliw3izVFXwgQcpxBS8n.png?auto=format&w=1098 1098w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/zliw3izVFXwgQcpxBS8n.png?auto=format&w=1252 1252w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/zliw3izVFXwgQcpxBS8n.png?auto=format&w=1320 1320w" width="660">
<figcaption>
Omnibox bug with zoom and install icons present.
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>I decided to investigate our user's perception, as most feedback was
anecdotal. Working with our UX researchers, we ran a study with
10,000 users in the USA and Indonesia to determine users'
understanding of install iconography. We tested five different
designs, including the existing one, and asked users what &quot;Install&quot;
meant. We discovered that the current icon, the plus symbol, was the
most confusing to our users. Many confused the symbol
with &quot;medicine&quot;, &quot;first aid&quot; and &quot;batteries&quot;.</p>
<p>We also found that users primarily associated imagery such as arrows
and devices with the install. Based on these conclusions, we ran an
A/B/C test in Chrome, comparing the existing design with two
alternatives. We landed on the arrow pointing down into a monitor,
which performed significantly better than the other two. We also saw
a decrease in dismissals of the install UI with this new icon.</p>
<figure>
<img alt="Install icon variants from the Material Design icon set." decoding="async" height="240" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 588px) 588px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/Wb3UqwvqaNGxVJ1ztp9X.png?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/Wb3UqwvqaNGxVJ1ztp9X.png?auto=format&w=200 200w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/Wb3UqwvqaNGxVJ1ztp9X.png?auto=format&w=228 228w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/Wb3UqwvqaNGxVJ1ztp9X.png?auto=format&w=260 260w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/Wb3UqwvqaNGxVJ1ztp9X.png?auto=format&w=296 296w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/Wb3UqwvqaNGxVJ1ztp9X.png?auto=format&w=338 338w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/Wb3UqwvqaNGxVJ1ztp9X.png?auto=format&w=385 385w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/Wb3UqwvqaNGxVJ1ztp9X.png?auto=format&w=439 439w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/Wb3UqwvqaNGxVJ1ztp9X.png?auto=format&w=500 500w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/Wb3UqwvqaNGxVJ1ztp9X.png?auto=format&w=571 571w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/Wb3UqwvqaNGxVJ1ztp9X.png?auto=format&w=650 650w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/Wb3UqwvqaNGxVJ1ztp9X.png?auto=format&w=741 741w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/Wb3UqwvqaNGxVJ1ztp9X.png?auto=format&w=845 845w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/Wb3UqwvqaNGxVJ1ztp9X.png?auto=format&w=964 964w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/Wb3UqwvqaNGxVJ1ztp9X.png?auto=format&w=1098 1098w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/Wb3UqwvqaNGxVJ1ztp9X.png?auto=format&w=1176 1176w" width="588">
<figcaption>
Variants of our install iconography that you can download from our 
Material Design icon set.
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>The outcome is the design you see today, which has seen the install
rate for PWAs more than double for websites. We have also added this
icon and a mobile equivalent to our <a href="https://fonts.google.com/icons?selected=Material+Icons+Outlined:assignment_returned&amp;icon.query=install+">Material Design icon set</a>,
enabling the community to use the iconography that we found most
engaging.</p>
<p>Of course, a single icon will not change the world, which leads us to
our next feature.</p>
<h2 id="iph" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#iph" aria-hidden="true">#</a> In-product help </h2>
<p>In-Product Help is a blue bubble tooltip that onboards users on new
features that may interest them based on specific criteria. We
decided to launch this design pattern to inform users about the
install features and further support the new icon redesign.</p>
<figure>
<img alt="The in-product help bubble." decoding="async" height="250" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 547px) 547px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/jsUweHcawGwgwcZKH5by.jpg?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/jsUweHcawGwgwcZKH5by.jpg?auto=format&w=200 200w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/jsUweHcawGwgwcZKH5by.jpg?auto=format&w=228 228w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/jsUweHcawGwgwcZKH5by.jpg?auto=format&w=260 260w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/jsUweHcawGwgwcZKH5by.jpg?auto=format&w=296 296w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/jsUweHcawGwgwcZKH5by.jpg?auto=format&w=338 338w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/jsUweHcawGwgwcZKH5by.jpg?auto=format&w=385 385w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/jsUweHcawGwgwcZKH5by.jpg?auto=format&w=439 439w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/jsUweHcawGwgwcZKH5by.jpg?auto=format&w=500 500w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/jsUweHcawGwgwcZKH5by.jpg?auto=format&w=571 571w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/jsUweHcawGwgwcZKH5by.jpg?auto=format&w=650 650w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/jsUweHcawGwgwcZKH5by.jpg?auto=format&w=741 741w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/jsUweHcawGwgwcZKH5by.jpg?auto=format&w=845 845w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/jsUweHcawGwgwcZKH5by.jpg?auto=format&w=964 964w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/jsUweHcawGwgwcZKH5by.jpg?auto=format&w=1094 1094w" width="547">
<figcaption>
In-product help tooltip bubble that educates users about features.
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>When a user visits a website regularly, Chrome uses a service known
as <a href="https://www.chromium.org/developers/design-documents/site-engagement">Site Engagement</a>.
This provides information about how engaged a user is with a site. By
visiting <code>chrome://site-engagement/</code>, you can see the sites that you
are engaging with regularly. Using these scores, we could determine
if a user is interested in a website. If the site was a PWA and the
user was engaged we would show them the install In-Product Help UI.
This meant that we only focused on engaged users and not annoy users
who may visit a site one time.</p>
<p>By using in-product help on desktop, we saw a greater than 100%
increase in PWA installation, showing that focusing on engaged users
improved the installability of web apps.</p>
<h2 id="richer" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#richer" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Richer Install UI</h2>
<p>The install paradigm for most users is a store.
Since the mid-2000's we have educated users that whenever they are
installing an app, they will see a description, screenshots, and
other metadata to help them decide if an app is something they
want.</p>
<p>With PWAs, the UI we showed once a user had decided to install a web
app was relatively meager. So the team decided to explore a richer
install experience that would give context to our users about the web
app and enable developers to celebrate the PWA's that were on par
with native experiences.</p>
<figure>
<img alt="Richer install UI." decoding="async" height="776" loading="lazy" sizes="(min-width: 800px) 800px, calc(100vw - 48px)" src="https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/8kGMXy7tkoZMKr4y0qEY.jpg?auto=format" srcset="https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/8kGMXy7tkoZMKr4y0qEY.jpg?auto=format&w=200 200w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/8kGMXy7tkoZMKr4y0qEY.jpg?auto=format&w=228 228w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/8kGMXy7tkoZMKr4y0qEY.jpg?auto=format&w=260 260w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/8kGMXy7tkoZMKr4y0qEY.jpg?auto=format&w=296 296w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/8kGMXy7tkoZMKr4y0qEY.jpg?auto=format&w=338 338w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/8kGMXy7tkoZMKr4y0qEY.jpg?auto=format&w=385 385w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/8kGMXy7tkoZMKr4y0qEY.jpg?auto=format&w=439 439w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/8kGMXy7tkoZMKr4y0qEY.jpg?auto=format&w=500 500w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/8kGMXy7tkoZMKr4y0qEY.jpg?auto=format&w=571 571w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/8kGMXy7tkoZMKr4y0qEY.jpg?auto=format&w=650 650w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/8kGMXy7tkoZMKr4y0qEY.jpg?auto=format&w=741 741w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/8kGMXy7tkoZMKr4y0qEY.jpg?auto=format&w=845 845w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/8kGMXy7tkoZMKr4y0qEY.jpg?auto=format&w=964 964w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/8kGMXy7tkoZMKr4y0qEY.jpg?auto=format&w=1098 1098w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/8kGMXy7tkoZMKr4y0qEY.jpg?auto=format&w=1252 1252w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/8kGMXy7tkoZMKr4y0qEY.jpg?auto=format&w=1428 1428w, https://wd.imgix.net/image/xizoeLGxYNf3VLUHc5BsIoiE1Af1/8kGMXy7tkoZMKr4y0qEY.jpg?auto=format&w=1600 1600w" width="800">
<figcaption>
Richer Install UI, collapsed and expanded states.
</figcaption>
</figure>
<p>Earlier this year, we launched <a href="https://developer.chrome.com/blog/richer-pwa-installation/">Richer Install</a>,
an extended install UI on Chrome on Android that allows developers to
add screenshots to their manifest. Developers can also add a
description, which is recommended but not necessary. Due to this
newer UI, we saw an install rate for some PWAs double, showing that
users have greater confidence in installing web apps when we give
more context and richer experiences.. The desktop version of this UI
is currently a work in progress.</p>
<h2 id="conclusion" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#conclusion" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Conclusion</h2>
<p>The team has spent the last two years exploring and
experimenting with newer features in Chrome that have enabled and
empowered PWA developers and helped to educate users about the
benefits of web experiences. There is still plenty of work we can
do, but collectively we can improve and enrich our users' lives
and further support the open web.</p>
</content>

    <title>Deprecations and removals in Chrome 97</title>
    <link href="https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/deps-rems-97/" />
    <updated>2021-11-22T00:00:00+00:00</updated>
    <id>https://developer.chrome.com/en/blog/deps-rems-97/</id>
    
    <author>
      <name>Chrome Developers</name>
    </author>
    
    <content type="html"><div class="aside aside--note">
<p>Visit ChromeStatus.com for lists of <a href="https://www.chromestatus.com/features#browsers.chrome.status%3A%22Deprecated%22">current deprecations</a> and <a href="https://www.chromestatus.com/features#browsers.chrome.status:%22Removed%22">previous removals</a>.</p>
</div>
<p>Chrome 97 beta was released on November 18, 2021 and is expected to become the
stable version in late December, 2021.</p>
<h2 id="remove-sdes-key-exchange-for-webrtc" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#remove-sdes-key-exchange-for-webrtc" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Remove SDES key exchange for WebRTC</h2>
<p>The SDES key exchange mechanism for WebRTC has been declared a MUST NOT in the
relevant IETF standards since 2013. The SDES specification has been declared
historic by the IETF. Its usage in Chrome has declined significantly over the
recent year. Consequently <a href="https://www.chromestatus.com/feature/5695324321480704">it is
removed</a> as of Chrome
97.</p>
<h2 id="remove-websql-in-third-party-contexts" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#remove-websql-in-third-party-contexts" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Remove WebSQL in third-party contexts</h2>
<p><a href="https://www.chromestatus.com/feature/5684870116278272">WebSQL in third-party contexts is now removed</a>.
The Web SQL Database standard was first proposed in April 2009 and abandoned in
November 2010. Gecko never implemented this feature and WebKit deprecated it in
2019. The W3C encourages
<a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/Web_Storage_API">Web Storage</a>
and
<a href="https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/IndexedDB_API">Indexed Database</a>
for those needing alternatives.</p>
<h2 id="remove-sdp-plan-b" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#remove-sdp-plan-b" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Remove SDP Plan B</h2>
<p>The Session Description Protocol (SDP) used to establish a session in WebRTC has
been implemented with two different dialects in Chromium: Unified Plan and Plan
B. Plan B is not cross-browser compatible and <a href="https://www.chromestatus.com/features/5823036655665152">is hereby
removed</a>.</p>
<h2 id="deprecation-policy" tabindex="-1"><a class="heading-link" href="#deprecation-policy" aria-hidden="true">#</a> Deprecation policy</h2>
<p>To keep the platform healthy, we sometimes remove APIs from the Web Platform
which have run their course. There can be many reasons why we would remove an
API, such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>They are superseded by newer APIs.</li>
<li>They are updated to reflect changes to specifications to bring alignment and
consistency with other browsers.</li>
<li>They are early experiments that never came to fruition in other browsers and
thus can increase the burden of support for web developers.</li>
</ul>
<p>Some of these changes will have an effect on a very small number of sites. To
mitigate issues ahead of time, we try to give developers advanced notice so they
can make the required changes to keep their sites running.</p>
<p>Chrome currently has a <a href="http://www.chromium.org/blink#TOC-Launch-Process:-Deprecation">process for deprecations and removals of
API's</a>,
essentially:</p>
<ul>
<li>Announce on the
<a href="https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/forum/#!forum/blink-dev">blink-dev</a>
mailing list.</li>
<li>Set warnings and give time scales in the Chrome DevTools Console when usage
is detected on the page.</li>
<li>Wait, monitor, and then remove the feature as usage drops.</li>
</ul>
<p>You can find a list of all deprecated features on chromestatus.com using the
<a href="https://www.chromestatus.com/features#deprecated">deprecated filter</a> and
removed features by applying the <a href="https://www.chromestatus.com/features#removed">removed
filter</a>. We will also try to
summarize some of the changes, reasoning, and migration paths in these posts.</p>
</content>
